newsitem.title: CHINA: China denies Moslem region rocked by bomb attack.
newsitem.headline: China denies Moslem region rocked by bomb attack.

text.p: China on Tuesday denied its restive northwestern region of Xinjiang had been hit by a new bomb attack after three bus bombings last week killed seven people and wounded more than 60.
"It's peaceful here. There's been no untoward incident," a government official in Yining, or Kuldji, said by telephone.

Mukhiddin Mukhlisi, an exiled spokesman for Uighur nationalists, told Reuters in the Kazakh capital Almaty that his group had staged a bomb attack on a Chinese bus in Kuldji on Monday in reprisal for Beijing government measures against the Moslem ethnic group.
"There have been a lot rumours like this recently... There was no new bomb attack," another official said.

Mukhlisi accused the Chinese police and army of killing 127 Uighurs and arresting hundreds more in a campaign against nationalists seeking an independent homeland, which he said was launched last month.
Mukhlisi said Chinese authorities were pursuing a deliberate policy of bringing in ethnic Han Chinese immigrants to Xinjiang and giving them favourable treatment over Uighurs.

Last week's time-bombs coincided with funeral rites for China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping and were the latest example of brewing unrest in the oil-rich region, where most of China's Turkic-speaking Uighurs live.
In February, a huge anti-Chinese riot by local Uighurs broke out in Yining. Chinese officials said nine people were killed.
The riot was one of the largest, most violent demonstrations for independence in Xinjiang since the 1949 communist takeover.
